messageBody:
Many of my tests wind up being nearly as long as the class being
tested... I have no desire to double the size of my code with tests. Plus,
tests that exist within the classes they are testing will ultimately get
compiled along with the classes, increasing the size of your distributions
needlessly.

I go with the separate-yet-parallel directory structure route, and
tend to make most methods protected rather than private to allow them to be
tested. I'm sure someone will chime in shortly for logic surrounding only
testing public methods.

-tim

-----Original Message-----
From: David Stagner [mailto:dstagner@...]
Sent: Friday, March 29, 2002 2:38 PM
To: junit@yahoogroups.com
Subject: Re: [junit] testing private methods


Nilesh Thali wrote:

> Actually, we would like to keep our tests as a completely separate package
to
>
> prevent it from obscuring the actual code base...

Choose your poison, then. If you want to keep your test classes
completely separate from the classes tested, then you'll only be testing
the public interface (and you need to feel certain all your private
methods work when they can only be tested indirectly via the public
interface). If you want to test private methods directly, you must run
your tests as inner classes.

Why do you think tests "obscure" the code base, though? If you use an
inner class, just put it at the very bottom of the source file, and
programmers should be able to just ignore it. If you use a consistent
naming scheme, programmers can also ignore test methods in whatever IDE
you're using. Alternately, you could put the tests in separate classes
in the same package, so you can test package-local methods.

Personally, i don't like the idea of putting unit tests in a separate
package, for two reasons - first, the tests would only have access to
public methods, not package or private methods. This makes test-first
coding harder, as the private methods can only be observed indirectly.
And second, it makes it too easy to ignore the test suite, "just this
one time", which leads to untested code. But this is very much my own
opinion on how things should be done.
